text: I really enjoyed this film. The storyline is not your usual rom/com, and yes, it has a stronger sense of loss through the female lead (Chopra). That is what I enjoyed about this movie though. It really draws you into the pain Mira feels and what true love feel like, while providing the predictable sense of hope that you can go on and love…again.
Anything else goes out of the window when it makes you feel good.

The idea is interesting and, although it vaguely resembles "P.S.: I Love You", it has its touches of originality. I loved the presence of Queen Celine Dion, but the jokes about the songs and the "therapy" sessions with her seemed quite forced. They weren't necessary. I think it had the right touch of drama to keep the film light and I sympathized with the protagonists. I had fun and didn't have any grudges against anyone, so it's worth it!

Finally got around to watching *Love Again* after a year on my watchlist. Honestly, the only reason I was interested was Celine Dion, and she did not disappoint! Her songs fit perfectly, and she acts surprisingly well—she’s more than just a cameo, which was such a fun surprise. The plot? Cheesy and cliché, but isn’t that what we’re here for in a romcom like this? It’s cozy, lighthearted, and gave me a few chuckles. 

That said, it’s definitely not groundbreaking. The pacing drags a bit in places, and with sharper writing and editing, it could’ve been so much better. Still, I was never bored, and it’s a decent pick when you’re in the mood for something romantic but not too demanding. Definitely a “background movie” vibe, but hey, sometimes that’s all you need. A solid 3-star watch for a cozy night in!

"Love Again" is a theatrical release that feels more like a streaming service movie, with its lackluster storytelling and underdeveloped characters. Priyanka delivers a solid performance, but the film falls short in creating meaningful connections between the characters, especially the main character and her deceased boyfriend.

The concept of the phones being in someone else's name and the subsequent texting adds a touch of intrigue, but the execution lacks depth. The predictable and drawn-out love story fails to deliver the excitement that could have elevated the plot.

Celine Dion's appearance as herself in the film adds a layer of authenticity, with many of her lines reflecting her real-life experiences with Renee. However, her portrayal comes across as cold and self-absorbed, casting her in an unfavorable light. This portrayal may alienate viewers who are not die-hard fans of Celine Dion, painting her as the villain rather than a relatable protagonist.

Overall, "Love Again" falls short of expectations and fails to leave a lasting impression. With its unengaging plot and unlikable characters, it is not a film worth revisiting or recommending. This lackluster production earns a disappointing half-star rating.
